Mohamed El Sayed the Canvas only work if you have your html online normal. in my case i'm loading a scaled iframe and i want to generate a screenshot from this iFrame. 

I tried most of the services that exist and so far the best wa url2png but they have a HUGEEE delay in their API response other services cause issues with fonts rendering.

JS Solutions like PhantomJS failed big time. I also tried Flash and Flex. My only solution now is to use Java. I think this is the only way left.

It's really amazing how all the screenshots services SUCKS and they are so fuckin Expensive and the cheap ones give you a very small API calls per day.

The problem in my case is that the iFrame contents change every time you refresh the page so i can't use a service and cache the screenshot image :S and i can't load too many iframes on the same page because it will cause memory leaks in browser and my target browsers are (IE9+, Chrome latest and FF Latest).

Did you try loading the iframe in a SVG foreignObject then using the SVG as an image and draw it on a canvas then take a photo of the canvas? But anyway why don't you make your own server-side solution? it will be very much easier that all this
ok so the conclusion of this experiment is that there is no way to achieve what i wanted.
